p: The total polyphenol content decreased significantly ( p < 0.05) after blanching as reported by [ 31, 32, 33, 34]. In addition, Gawlik-Dziki [ 35] demonstrated that boiling significantly reduced the polyphenol content of fresh broccoli. Similarly, Sikora et al. [ 36] reported a significant decrease in total polyphenol and antioxidant components in boiled broccoli. Abu-Ghannam and Jaiswal [ 37] described a reduction in the total phenolic content of up to 45% at lower blanching temperatures (80–90 °C) within 2 min of blanching and reduction of the total polyphenol content continued within 6 min at high blanching temperatures . Furthermore, as some authors have observed, the degree of leaf fragmentation may be a factor in a greater diffusion of the bioactive compounds from the leaves to the water.
